Fancy, bright and winged maid!</br>In thy night-drawn car conveyed,</br>O'er the green earth and wide-spread main,</br>A thousand shadows in thy train,</br>A varied, air-embodied host,</br>To don what shapes thou pleasest most;</br>Brandish no more thy scorpion stings</br>Around the destined couch of kings;</br>Nor in rebellion's ghastly size</br>A dire gigantic spectre rise:</br>Cease, for a while, in rooms of state</br>To damp the slumbers of the great;</br>In merit's lean-looked form to appear,</br>And holloa traitor in their ear:</br>Or freedom's holier garb belie,</br>While justice grinds her axe fast by:</br>Nor o'er the miser's eyelids pour</br>The unrefreshing golden shower;</br>Whilst, keen the unreal bliss to feel,</br>His breast bedews the ruffian steel.

With these (when next thou tak'st thy round)</br>The thoughts of guilty pride confound:</br>These swell the horrors and affright</br>Of conscience' keen condemning night.</br>For this (nor, gracious power!  repine)</br>A gentler ministry be thine:</br>Whate'er inspires the poet's theme,</br>Or lover's hope-enlivened dream.</br>MONIMIA's mildest form assume;</br>Spread o'er thy cheeks her youthful bloom;</br>Unfold her eyes unblemished rays,</br>That melt to virtue as we gaze;</br>That envy's guiltiest wish disarm,</br>And view benign a kindred charm:</br>Call all the graces from thy store,</br>Till thy creative power be o'er;</br>Bid her each breathing sweet dispense,</br>And robe in her own innocence.

My wish is given:  the spells begin;</br>The ideal world awakes within;</br>The lonely void of still repose</br>Pregnant with some new wonder grows;</br>See, by the twilight of the skies,</br>The beauteous apparition rise;</br>Slow, in MONIMIA's form, along</br>Glides to the harmony of song.

But who is he the virgin leads,</br>Whom high a flaming torch precedes,</br>In a gown of stainless lawn,</br>O'er each manly shoulder drawn?</br>Who, clad in robe of scarlet grain,</br>The boy that bears her flowing train?</br>Behind his back a quiver hung,</br>A bended bow across is flung;</br>His head and heels two wings unfold,</br>The azure feathers girt with gold.</br>Hymen!  'tis he who kind inspires</br>Joys unfeign'd and chaste desires.</br>And thou, of Love, deceitful child!</br>With tiger-heart, yet lamb-like mild,</br>Fantastic by thyself, and vain,</br>But seemly seen in Hymen's train;</br>If Fate be to my wishes kind,</br>O!  may I find ye ever join'd;</br>But if the Fates my wish deny,</br>My humble roof come ye not nigh.

The spell works on:  yet stop the day</br>While in the house of sleep I stay.</br>About me swells the sudden grove,</br>The woven arbourette of Love;</br>Flow'rs spring unbidden o'er the ground,</br>And more than nature plants around.</br>Fancy, prolong the kind repose;</br>Still, still th' enchanting vision glows;</br>And now I gaze o'er all her charms,</br>Now sink transported in her arms.</br>Oh sacred energy divine!</br>All these enraptur'd scenes are thine.</br>Hail!  copious source of pure delight;</br>All hail!  thou heaven-revealed rite;</br>Endearing Truth thy train attends,</br>And thou and meek-ey'd Peace are friends:</br>Closer entwine the magic bow'r;</br>Thick rain the rose-empurpl'd show'r;</br>The mystic joy impatient flies</br>Th' unhallow'd gaze of vulgar eyes.</br>Unenvied let the rich and great</br>Turmoil without, and parcel Fate,</br>Indulging here, in bliss supreme,</br>Might I enjoy the golden dream:</br>But, ah!  the rapture must not stay;</br>For see!  she glides, she glides away.

Oh Fancy!  why did'st thou decoy</br>My thoughts into this dream of joy,</br>Then to forsake me all alone,</br>To mourn the fond delusion gone?</br>O!  back again, benign, restore</br>The pictur'd vision as before.</br>Yes, yes:  once more I fold my eyes;</br>Arise, ye dear deceits, arise.</br>Ideas bland!  where do ye rove?</br>Why fades my visionary grove?</br>Ye fickle troop of Morpheus' train,</br>Then will you, to the proud and vain,</br>From me, fantastic, wing your flight,</br>T' adorn the dream of false delight?</br>But now, seen in MONIMIA's air,</br>Can you assume a form less fair,</br>Some idle Beauty's wish supply,</br>The mimic triumphs of her eye?</br>Grant all to me this live-long night,</br>Let charms detain the rising light;</br>For this one night my liv'ries wear,</br>And I absolve you for the year.

What time your poppy-crowned God</br>Sends his truth-telling scouts abroad,</br>Ere yet the cock to matins rings,</br>And the lark with mounting wings,</br>The simple village swain has warn'd</br>To shake off sleep by labour earn'd;</br>Or on the rose's silken hem,</br>Aurora weeps her earliest gem;</br>Or beneath the opening dawn,</br>Smiles the fair-extended lawn.</br>When in the soft encircled shade</br>Ye find reclined the gentle maid,</br>Each busy motion laid to rest,</br>And all compos'd her peaceful breast:</br>Swift paint the fair internal scene,</br>The phantom labours of your reign;</br>The living imag'ry adorn</br>With all the limnings of the morn,</br>With all the treasures nature keeps</br>Conceal'd below the forming deeps;</br>Or dress'd in the rich waving pride,</br>That covers the green mountain's side,</br>Or blooms beneath the am'rous gale</br>In the wide embosom'd vale.</br>Let pow'rful Music too essay</br>The magic of her hidden lay:</br>While each harsh thought away shall fly</br>Down the full stream of harmony,</br>Compassion mild shall fill their place,</br>Each gentle minister of grace,</br>Pity, that often melts to Love,</br>Let weeping Pity, kind improve,</br>The soften'd heart, prepar'd to take</br>Whate'er impressions Love shall make.</br>Oh!  in that kind, that sacred hour,</br>When Hate, when Anger have no pow'r;</br>When sighing Love, mild simple boy,</br>Courtship sweet, and tender joy,</br>Alone possess the fair one's heart;</br>Let me then, Fancy, bear my part.

Oh goddess!  how I long t' appear;</br>The hour of dear success draws near:</br>See where the crowding shadows wait;</br>Haste and unfold the iv'ry gate:</br>Ye gracious forms, employ your aid,</br>Come in my anxious look array'd,</br>Come Love, come Hymen, at my pray'r</br>Led by blyth Hope, ye decent pair</br>By mutual confidence combin'd,</br>As erst in sleep I saw you join'd.</br>Fill my eyes with heart-swell'd tears,</br>Fill my breast with heart-born fears,</br>Half-utter'd vows and half-suppress'd,</br>Part look'd, and only wish'd the rest;</br>Make sighs, and speaking sorrows prove,</br>Suffering much, how much I love;</br>Make the Muse's lyre complain,</br>Strung by me in warbled strain;</br>Let the melodious numbers flow</br>Pow'rful of a lover's woe,</br>Till, by the tender Orphean art,</br>I through her ear shall gain her heart.
Now, Fancy, now the fit is o'er;</br>I feel my sorrows vex no more:</br>But when condemn'd again to mourn,</br>Fancy, to my aid return.</br>
